fuzzy Package¶

fuzzy Package¶

Module to implement fuzzy MSMs

analysis Module¶

Do analysis on MSMs after they have been built.

fuzzy.analysis.get_implied_timescales(t_matrix, n_timescales=4, lag_time=1)¶

Get implied timescales from a transition matrix.

fuzzy.analysis.plot_lambda_bar(implied_timescales, descs, logplot=False)¶

Plot implied timescales on a bar chart.

buildmsm Module¶

Code for building MSMs in some sort of fuzzy scheme.

fuzzy.buildmsm.build_classic_from_memberships(memberships, lag_time=1)¶

Build a classic msm by turning a membership array into a state list.

This function uses msmbuilder code to calculate the count matrix. Use this for compairing quantized versions of the fuzzy count matrix building for consistency.

fuzzy.buildmsm.build_from_memberships(memberships, lag_time=1)¶

Build an MSM from a time array of membership vectors.

fuzzy.buildmsm.get_counts_from_pairs(time_pairs, n_states)¶

Get a soft count matrix by using the outer product

time_pairs is a (n_points, 2, n_states) shaped matrix containing pairs of membership vectors.

fuzzy.buildmsm.get_counts_from_traj_soft1(states, n_states=None, lag_time=1)¶
fuzzy.buildmsm.get_counts_from_traj_soft2(states, n_states=None, lag_time=1)¶

Try to get a soft count matrix according to Tavan 2005.

states is a chronological list of states from which this function will calculate time pairs.

classic Module¶

Build an MSM using classic methods.

class fuzzy.classic.Euclidean2d(metric='euclidean', p=2, V=None, VI=None)¶

Bases: msmbuilder.metrics.baseclasses.Vectorized

prepare_trajectory(trajectory)¶
fuzzy.classic.msm(traj_list, n_clusters, n_medoid_iters=10, lag_time=1)¶

Use classic clustering methods.

get_data Module¶

class fuzzy.get_data.ShimTrajectory(xyz)¶

Bases: dict

This is a dict that can be used to interface some xyz coordinates with MSMBuilder’s clustering algorithms.

I’m really sorry that this is necessary. It’s horridly ugly, but it comes from the fact that I want to use the mdtraj trajectory object (its better), but the msmbuilder code hasn’t been rewritted to use the mdtraj trajectory yet. Soon, we will move mdtraj into msmbuilder, and this won’t be necessary.

fuzzy.get_data.get_points(stride, directory='../test_trajs/', dim=2)¶

Returns a numpy array of xy points.

fuzzy.get_data.get_points_from_trajlist(traj_list)¶

Get a list of points from multiple trajectories.

This can be used for clustering, mixture modeling, etc but is inappropriate for e.g. training an HMM.

fuzzy.get_data.get_shimtraj_from_trajlist(traj_list)¶

Get a shimmed trajectory from a list of points.

Used for using classic clustering from a constructed model.

fuzzy.get_data.get_trajs(directory='../test_trajs/', dim=2, retrieve='justpoints')¶

Get a list of trajectories.

Use retrieve to determine type:
  • ‘justpoints’: x and y coordinates of the first particle in a numpy

    array, list of

  • ‘mdtrajs’: mdtraj objects, list of

  • ‘shimtrajs’: trajectories suitable for use with msmbuilder2

mixture Module¶

Use mixture modeling and HMM to build a transition matrix.

fuzzy.mixture.get_hidden_markov_model(mixture_model, guess_t_matrix)¶

Get an (unoptomized) hidden markov model from the mixture model and a guess at the transition matrix.

The guess transition matrix is typically created by summing over the outer product of time-pairs of membership vectors.

fuzzy.mixture.get_mixture_model(points, min_k, max_k, fix_k=None)¶

Find the best mixture model based on BIC.

fuzzy.mixture.hmm(traj_list, min_k=3, max_k=20, fix_k=None, lag_time=1, sliding_window=True)¶

Build a hidden markov model from a list of trajectories.

This function will first create a mixture model and then use the Baum-Welch algorithm to learn the hidden transition matrix.

The number of mixture components can be determined by maximizing the BIC or by specifying a fixed number

Parameters:
  • traj_list (list) – List of tranjectories
  • min_k (int) – The number at which to start searching for the optimal number of mixture components
  • max_k (int) – The maximum number of mixture components to use.
  • fix_k (int or None) – If none, find the best number of mixture components within restraints. Otherwise, use precisely fix_k number of components
  • lag_time (int) – The lag time of the model. #TODO: This doesn’t do anything maybe
  • sliding_window (bool) – Whether to use a sliding window with lag_time
Returns:

scipy.sparse.csr_matrix – transition matrix
fuzzy.mixture.perform_optimization(hidden_mm, trajs, lag_time, sliding_window=True, n_steps=1000)¶

Optimize a hidden markov model given a list of trajectories.

Use the Baum-Welch algorithm for learning the transition matrix, fixing emission probabilities.

fuzzy.mixture.plot_distribution(mixture_model, grid, n_contours=80)¶

Plot the mixture distribution.

fuzzy.mixture.print_ic(mixture_model, points, desc='')¶

Status for finding a mixture model.

fuzzy.mixture.quantize_memberships(memberships)¶

For testing purposes, quantize membership vectors to be step functions

The new memberships will be of the form 0, 0, ..., 0, 1, 0, ..., 0. The occupied state will be the state with the highest occupation.

Use this function to test that building an msm from memberships produces the same results as building an msm from a state list with the msmbuilder package.

validate Module¶

class fuzzy.validate.ValidationData(n_its, *params)¶

Container for our various results.

get_param_iter()¶

Make an iterator over all permutations of parameters.

translate_to_values(param_is)¶

Take a tuple of indices and turn it into a list of values.

class fuzzy.validate.Validator(tmatrix_fn, num_trajs, traj_len, stride, n_its)¶
calculate_analytic_its()¶

Calculate analytic results.

calculate_hmm()¶

Calculate results for HMM.

calculate_its(tmat_func, anal_func, set_func)¶

Calculate implied timescales given appropriate functions.

This function calls vd.get_param_iter() to get the parameter indices over which to iterate and apply the provided functions.

Parameters:
  • tmat_func – tmat_func(traj_list, *params) that returns a transition matrix given parameters
  • anal_func – anal_func(t_matrix, *params) that returns implied timescales given a transition matrix and parameters
  • set_func – set_func(param_is, its) that is responsible for saving the results, its, at parameter indices param_is
calculate_msm()¶

Calculate results for MSM.

fuzzy.validate.main(tmatrix_fn='transition_matrix.pickl', num_trajs=100, traj_len=5000, stride=10, n_its=6, results_fn='validation_results.pickl')¶

Call the calculation steps in order and write the results to disk.
